newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS-Markets shrug off rate cut.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS-Markets shrug off rate cut.

text.p: An Australian rate cut failed to galvanise the Australian or Asian debt markets, although it helped erode the Australian dollar on Friday.

But bankers said the 50 basis points cut in the official cash rate by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) might inspire some fixed-rate issuance from Asian investors who believed Australian rates were near bottom.
The RBA rate cut was the fourth since July 1996, and took rates to their lowest level since August 1994.
A banker with a large Australian financial institution said spreads came in after the rate cut.
He said the Australian 10-year bond was trading at 85 basis points over the U.S. 10-year Treasury after the rate cut, down from 100 basis points before the cut.
One year ago, the spread was 200 basis points, he said.
There was a feeling that this might be the last RBA rate cut of the latest cycle, he said.
While issuers might want to lock in low rates through a fixed-rate issue, he saw more scope for an Australian dollar floating-rate note issue like a "Kangaroo" bond.
He predicted that the next entrants to the Kangaroo market would be a sovereign Asian issuer and a Hong Kong corporate.
The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) launched its 6.0 billion Taiwan dollar ($215 million) seven-year bond overnight Thursday in the domestic market.
The Taipei-listed notes carry a 6.04 percent coupon and were priced to yield 26 basis points over government bonds.
Despite the woes of Thai financial markets, Jasmine Submarine Telecoms said it was raising US$180 million through a 14-year bond.
Indian textile-maker Arvind Mills Ltd surfaced with its US$100 million floating-rate note through UBS in Hong Kong on Friday, and said to be 130 basis points over the London Interbank Offered Rate.
Bankers said Indian Railway Finance Corp IRLY.BO had cleared a hurdle by gaining permission to launch its US$150 million FRN next week via ANZ.
It may enter the market this week with the issue, although this has not been confirmed.
The Hong Kong dollar market had a quiet day, bankers said.
"It's like watching grass grow," said a local banker. "It's not really that active."
United Chinese Bank Ltd, a unit of Bank of East Asia Ltd privately placed a HK$300 million floating-rate certificate of deposit (FRCD).
The one-year FRCD pays a coupon of 25 basis points over the three month Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate.
